page.title: 04GEOLOGICAL SURVEY
page.content: The rocks in this map area all belong to the Carboniferous period. In the SW of the area under survey there is approx. 2.5 km2 of limestone.This land does not contain coal, but in the past was quarried for limestone. The predominate type of rock is limestone containing coal (carboniferous limestone). This covers about 9 km2 of the area. Over the past 100_150 years much of this area had a number of small coal mines. Today coal mining is represented by a large opencast development. The sedimentary rocks in this area have been greatly faulted which made mining difficult. The Hill of Beath, in the north of the area is made up of agglomerate rock; which is rock formed from a mass of volcanic debris,a result of volcanic activity at the end of the carboniferous period.
